answers.answer: I am the mom of an 18 year old who was diagnosed at the age of 21 months.  I am not a medical professional, so any advice given here should be verified with your daughter's healthcare team.  I am sorry to say that I do not have any first-hand knowledge of the types of insulin you are referring to, and we really cannot give advice about specific doses anyway, but I can share my opinion about her hypos with you.  First of all, have you done any 3am checks?  This is very good information to present to your daughter's endocrinologist and can sometimes give another clue as to why the erratic and higher morning bg's.  My daughter was very active as your daughter is with sports and her activity during the day would always catch up with her in the middle of the night.  I swear, sometimes she drank a juice box and ate some crackers while fast asleep!  If your daughter is bottoming out during the middle of the night, her body could be producing glucose to protect itself and thus creating a high morning bg.  A little less sleep for us parents is well worth obtaining better bg control.  Your daughter may also be ending her honeymoon phase.  That refers to the time period after diagnosis that the pancreas may be producing some insulin and therefore making proper dosing very difficult.  With the little ones, a lot of pediatric endocrinologists would rather have them be running on the higher side than take a chance with having them be running low.  Naturally, you should be in weekly contact with your daughter's healthcare team when you are not satisfied with her bg's.  Any type of consistant pattern of highs and or lows should be discussed with her physician so that dose changes can be made.  I hope that I have helped in some way and I am sure that others will have some more insight for you.  Good luck.
Had not heard of doing a 3am check - takes me back to having a newborn and night feeds!  Will put into action tonight.  Thank you.

Good for you!  Have you visited the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation's website?  You may want to as they can match you up with someone who has gone through this before and hopefully you can develop a relationship over the internet with someone who has "been there and done that"!  It's www.jdrf.org.  There's a newly diagnosed section that you should check out!  Good luck with your daughter & please let us know how she's doing!

question: Hi, my 8 year old daughter, diagnosed last September, has recently moved onto Mixtard30 (9units) at breakfast and Novarapid30 (2 - 4 units).  She is small for age - weight & height.  Sugars are very erratic.  Is there any reason why she cannot go onto a "home mix" regime.  I.e.I mix her insulin quantities - fast and long acting, appropriate to the meal she wants to eat not what she has to eat for the insulin as well as sorting out her high sugars - particularly in the morning.  She eats evening meal at 6.15pm.  Bed at 8.30pm.  Asleep at 9pmish.  Bedtime sugars often between 11-14mmol.  Midnight sugars 10mmol.  Morning 15 - 17mmol. WHY??!!  She is physically active - dance/sport amlost every day.  Could she be having delayed hypos hence the rise?  Really need some help here.  Thank you.
title: New insulins not working properly for 8 year old
